H0.text: Kinetic energy generated by the chemical reactions is the source of the energy stored in the up to 38 high‑energy ATP molecules produced from each glucose molecule during cellular respiration.

H1.text: Chemical energy originally stored in the glucose molecule is the source of the energy stored in the up to 38 high‑energy ATP molecules produced during cellular respiration.

H2.text: Electric current created during the destruction of electrons in the glucose is the source of the energy stored in the up to 38 high‑energy ATP molecules produced per glucose during cellular respiration.

H3.text: Potential energy from the difference in the concentration gradients of the cell is the source of the energy stored in the ATP molecules formed during cellular respiration, up to 38 high‑energy ATP per molecule of glucose.

A4.text: ATP is synthesized by the ATP synthase enzyme when the chemiosmotic gradient is used to drive the phosphorylation of ADP.
